would be a catalyst of creating a counter-culture + responsible for 
charting a cultural paradigm shift.

B) I think the term that you may have been searching for, but was resting 
far outside of your lexicon, is "social pathologies." If we are "getting 
real" Black people and all other racial/ethnic groups have social 
pathologies. What is more important is to understand and to examine the 
root/origin/context regarding the existence of said pathologies. In other 
words, what historical context, institutionalized ideas/values, and social 
structures contribute to human behavior? It is not enough to observe the 
dysfunctional behavior. In order to absolve said behavior one has to also 
be vocal about the history of institutionalized racism/white supremacy that 
has created inequalities that still persist.

I'd like to add that excessive violence, for example, is an American social 
pathology. It is not just a Black American social pathology. Despite this 
truth, inner-city gun violence is something that I want to work on 
decreasing/eradicating because I'm from a neighborhood where it was a 
problem. I've lost neighbors due to senseless gun violence. This brings me 
to my next point... There are organizations, community leaders, advocates, 
and civilians working fervently to address issues or social pathologies 
that impact the Black diaspora and/or all people. It is incorrect to 
insinuate that Blacks have "accepted" degernerate/exclusive conditions... 
as a group of people we've been working against the degenerate conditions 
that we've inherited since slavery. However, it takes centuries to undo the 
damage and trauma (physical and psychological) of systemic oppression, 
disenfranchisement, generational poverty, and cycles of violence which are 
by-products of ante-bellum slavery + Jim Crow laws + inhumane attitudes 
(that have even been documented in our declaration of independence i.e. the 
notion of a Black man being 3/5 a man) and other systems of oppression that 
are still at work in this country. Mind you, many of the systems of 
oppression are not just race-based they are class based and impact several 
different groups of people across this nation.
